file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Build Commands

```bash
cargo build --release    # Build release binary
cargo run -- <ADDR>      # Run with wall connector address
cargo clippy             # Lint
cargo test               # Run tests
```

## Architecture

Single-binary CLI tool that queries Tesla Wall Connector's local HTTP API. Uses clap for argument parsing, reqwest (blocking) for HTTP requests, and serde for JSON deserialization.

Entry point: `src/main.rs`

[package]
name = "tesla-wallcon-monitor"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2024"

[dependencies]
clap = { version = "4", features = ["derive"] }
reqwest = { version = "0.12", features = ["blocking", "json"] }
serde = { version = "1", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1"
base64 = "0.22"
crossterm = "0.28"
log = "0.4"
simplelog = "0.12"

content.content:
1→# tesla-wallcon-monitor
     2→
     3→A CLI tool to monitor a Tesla Wall Connector.
     4→
     5→This was created with `claude code opus 4.5` and I use a local directory,
     6→[./.claude](./.claude), to preserve claude-code musings.
     7→If you'd like to do the same for this or any other repo I created
     8→`claude-symlink.sh` which adds symlink's to `~/.claude/projects/`.
     9→If you have a default claude code installation you can run
    10→`claude-symlink.sh ./.claude`. For details see
    11→[https://github.com/winksaville/claude-symlink.sh](https://github.com/winksaville/claude-symlink.sh).
    12→
    13→## Building
    14→
    15→```bash
    16→$ cargo build --release
    17→   Compiling proc-macro2 v1.0.103
    18→   Compiling quote v1.0.42
    19→   Compiling unicode-ident v1.0.22
    20→   ..
    21→   Compiling hyper-tls v0.6.0
    22→   Compiling reqwest v0.12.26
    23→   Compiling tesla-wallcon-monitor v0.1.0 (/home/wink/data/prgs/tesla/tesla-wallcon-monitor)
    24→    Finished `release` profile [optimized] target(s) in 26.63s
    25→```
    26→
    27→## Usage
    28→
    29→```bash
    30→tesla-wallcon-monitor [OPTIONS] <ADDR> <COMMAND>
    31→```
    32→
    33→### Options
    34→
    35→- `-l, --loop-mode` - Continuously update display (vitals only). Press ESC or Ctrl+C to exit.
    36→- `-d, --delay <SECONDS>` - Delay between updates in loop mode (default: 5).
    37→- `--log <FILE>` - Log raw JSON responses with timestamps to a file for later processing.
    38→- `-h, --help` -  Print help
    39→
    40→### Commands
    41→
    42→Commands can be abbreviated to their minimum unique prefix:
    43→
    44→| Abbrev | Command      | Description                              |
    45→|--------|--------------|------------------------------------------|
    46→| l      | lifetime     | Display lifetime statistics              |
    47→| ve     | version      | Display firmware and device information  |
    48→| vi     | vitals       | Display real-time charging status        |
    49→| w      | wifi_status  | Display WiFi connection status           |
    50→
    51→### Examples
    52→
    53→```bash
    54→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor --help
    55→Monitor a Tesla Wall Connector
    56→
    57→Usage: tesla-wallcon-monitor [OPTIONS] <ADDR> <COMMAND>
    58→
    59→Arguments:
    60→  <ADDR>     Name or IP address of the wall connector
    61→  <COMMAND>  Command: (l)ifetime, (ve)rsion, (vi)tals, (w)ifi_status
    62→
    63→Options:
    64→  -l, --loop-mode      Loop mode: continuously update display (vitals only)
    65→  -d, --delay <DELAY>  Delay in seconds between updates in loop mode [default: 5]
    66→      --log <LOG>      Log file for debug output (JSON data with timestamps)
    67→  -h, --help           Print help
    68→
    69→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 vitals
    70→Tesla Wall Connector Vitals:
    71→  Vehicle Connected:  false
    72→  Contactor Closed:   false
    73→  Session Duration:   0m
    74→  Session Energy:     0.000 kWh
    75→  Vehicle Current:    0.0 A
    76→
    77→  Grid Voltage:       245.9 V
    78→  Grid Frequency:     59.867 Hz
    79→  Phase Currents:     A=0.0 B=0.0 C=0.0 N=0.0 A
    80→  Phase Voltages:     A=0.2 B=0.0 C=0.2 V
    81→
    82→  PCBA Temp:          21.9°C
    83→  Handle Temp:        19.5°C
    84→  MCU Temp:           29.3°C
    85→
    86→  Pilot High/Low:     11.8 / 11.8 V
    87→  Proximity:          0.5 V
    88→  Relay Coil:         0.0 V
    89→  Thermopile:         -84 uV
    90→
    91→  Uptime:             1d 4h 15m
    92→  EVSE State:         1
    93→  Config Status:      5
    94→  Not Ready Reasons:  [4, 8]
    95→
    96→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 lifetime
    97→Tesla Wall Connector Lifetime Stats:
    98→  Charge Starts:      1054
    99→  Energy Delivered:   5276.62 kWh
   100→  Charging Time:      45d 13h 54m
   101→  Uptime:             588d 0h 18m
   102→  Contactor Cycles:   1054
   103→  Loaded Cycles:      66
   104→  Connector Cycles:   483
   105→  Thermal Foldbacks:  0
   106→  Alert Count:        2243
   107→  Avg Startup Temp:   0.0°C
   108→
   109→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 version
   110→Tesla Wall Connector Version Info:
   111→  Firmware Version: 25.34.1+ge48cc9be91ebc7
   112→  Git Branch:       HEAD
   113→  Part Number:      1529455-02-D
   114→  Serial Number:    TWC123456789
   115→  Web Service:      0.1.0
   116→
   117→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 wifi_status
   118→Tesla Wall Connector WiFi Status:
   119→  SSID:            MyNetwork
   120→  Connected:       true
   121→  Signal Strength: 66%
   122→  RSSI:            -57 dBm
   123→  SNR:             36 dB
   124→  IP Address:      192.168.1.221
   125→  Internet:        true
   126→  MAC Address:     54:F8:F0:0A:30:AA
   127→```
   128→
   129→#### Example using loop with a 2 second delay to a log file:
   130→
   131→This is with a working Gen 3 WC writing to [./data/logs5tt-d-2.txt](./data/logs5tt-d-2.txt)
   132→
   133→```bash
   134→$ tesla-wallcon-monitor -l -d 2 --log data/logs5tt-d-2.txt
   135→```
   136→
   137→* vehicle_connected changes from false to true:
   138→```bash
   139→2025-12-23T02:54:29.498412289Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":false,"session_s":0,"grid_v":253.7,"grid_hz":59.854,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   140→2025-12-23T02:54:31.560979426Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":1,"grid_v":253.7,"grid_hz":59.843,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   141→  ```
   142→* We see contactor_closed change from false to true and vehicle_current_a starts increasing:
   143→```bash
   144→2025-12-23T02:54:45.953839436Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":16,"grid_v":253.7,"grid_hz":59.833,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   145→2025-12-23T02:54:48.094345771Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":true,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":18,"grid_v":253.5,"grid_hz":59.844,"vehicle_current_a":0.4,..
   146→  ```
   147→* Current reaches maximum:
   148→```bash
   149→2025-12-23T02:55:25.113653342Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":true,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":55,"grid_v":252.4,"grid_hz":59.873,"vehicle_current_a":40.1,..
   150→```
   151→* I stop charging and contactor_closed changes from true to false:
   152→```bash
   153→2025-12-23T02:55:43.547789191Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":true,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":73,"grid_v":252.2,"grid_hz":59.870,"vehicle_current_a":40.0,..
   154→2025-12-23T02:55:51.774753747Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":81,"grid_v":253.5,"grid_hz":59.874,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   155→```
   156→
   157→* vehicle_connected changes from true to false:
   158→```bash
   159→2025-12-23T02:56:08.221355598Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":true,"session_s":98,"grid_v":253.8,"grid_hz":59.868,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   160→2025-12-23T02:56:10.266724979Z [INFO] vitals: {"contactor_closed":false,"vehicle_connected":false,"session_s":0,"grid_v":253.9,"grid_hz":59.871,"vehicle_current_a":0.3,..
   161→```

file.content:
# tesla-wallcon-monitor

A CLI tool to monitor a Tesla Wall Connector.

This was created with `claude code opus 4.5` and I use a local directory,
[./.claude](./.claude), to preserve claude-code musings.
If you'd like to do the same for this or any other repo I created
`claude-symlink.sh` which adds symlink's to `~/.claude/projects/`.
If you have a default claude code installation you can run
`claude-symlink.sh ./.claude`. For details see
[https://github.com/winksaville/claude-symlink.sh](https://github.com/winksaville/claude-symlink.sh).

## Building

```bash
$ cargo build --release
   Compiling proc-macro2 v1.0.103
   Compiling quote v1.0.42
   Compiling unicode-ident v1.0.22
   ..
   Compiling hyper-tls v0.6.0
   Compiling reqwest v0.12.26
   Compiling tesla-wallcon-monitor v0.1.0 (/home/wink/data/prgs/tesla/tesla-wallcon-monitor)
    Finished `release` profile [optimized] target(s) in 26.63s
```

## Usage

```bash
tesla-wallcon-monitor [OPTIONS] <ADDR> <COMMAND>
```

### Options

- `-l, --loop-mode` - Continuously update display (vitals only). Press ESC or Ctrl+C to exit.
- `-d, --delay <SECONDS>` - Delay between updates in loop mode (default: 5).
- `--log <FILE>` - Log raw JSON responses with timestamps to a file for later processing.
- `-h, --help` -  Print help

### Commands

Commands can be abbreviated to their minimum unique prefix:

| Abbrev | Command      | Description                              |
|--------|--------------|------------------------------------------|
| l      | lifetime     | Display lifetime statistics              |
| ve     | version      | Display firmware and device information  |
| vi     | vitals       | Display real-time charging status        |
| w      | wifi_status  | Display WiFi connection status           |

### Examples

```bash
$ tesla-wallcon-monitor --help
Monitor a Tesla Wall Connector

Usage: tesla-wallcon-monitor [OPTIONS] <ADDR> <COMMAND>

Arguments:
  <ADDR>     Name or IP address of the wall connector
  <COMMAND>  Command: (l)ifetime, (ve)rsion, (vi)tals, (w)ifi_status

Options:
  -l, --loop-mode      Loop mode: continuously update display (vitals only)
  -d, --delay <DELAY>  Delay in seconds between updates in loop mode [default: 5]
      --log <LOG>      Log file for debug output (JSON data with timestamps)
  -h, --help           Print help

$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 vitals
Tesla Wall Connector Vitals:
  Vehicle Connected:  false
  Contactor Closed:   false
  Session Duration:   0m
  Session Energy:     0.000 kWh
  Vehicle Current:    0.0 A

  Grid Voltage:       245.9 V
  Grid Frequency:     59.867 Hz
  Phase Currents:     A=0.0 B=0.0 C=0.0 N=0.0 A
  Phase Voltages:     A=0.2 B=0.0 C=0.2 V

  PCBA Temp:          21.9°C
  Handle Temp:        19.5°C
  MCU Temp:           29.3°C

  Pilot High/Low:     11.8 / 11.8 V
  Proximity:          0.5 V
  Relay Coil:         0.0 V
  Thermopile:         -84 uV

  Uptime:             1d 4h 15m
  EVSE State:         1
  Config Status:      5
  Not Ready Reasons:  [4, 8]

$ tesla-wallcon-monitor 192.168.1.221 lifetime
Tesla Wall Connector Lifetime Stats:
  Charge Starts:      1054
```

input.new_string:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Build Commands

```bash
cargo build --release    # Build release binary
cargo run -- <ADDR> <CMD> # Run with wall connector address and command
cargo clippy             # Lint
cargo test               # Run tests
```

## Architecture

Single-binary CLI tool (`src/main.rs`) that queries Tesla Wall Connector Gen 3's local HTTP API at `http://<addr>/api/1/<endpoint>`.

**Dependencies**: clap (CLI parsing with derive), reqwest (blocking HTTP), serde/serde_json (JSON), crossterm (terminal UI for loop mode), simplelog (file logging), base64 (SSID decoding).

**API Endpoints & Data Structures**:
- `/vitals` → `Vitals` struct - real-time charging data (currents, voltages, temps, session info)
- `/lifetime` → `Lifetime` struct - cumulative stats (energy delivered, charge starts, uptime)
- `/version` → `Version` struct - firmware and device info
- `/wifi_status` → `WifiStatus` struct - network connection details

**Command Matching**: Commands use prefix matching via `match_command()`. Minimum unique prefixes: `l`=lifetime, `ve`=version, `vi`=vitals, `w`=wifi_status.

**Loop Mode**: The `vitals` command supports `-l/--loop-mode` which uses crossterm's raw mode for continuous display updates with ESC/Ctrl+C to exit.
